positive.review: Updates have made huge improvements, as have some of the UI mods. I dropped the game a few weeks after launch but am back playing it and am really enjoying it. The latest update, 1.3.0, has made the civs feel different to each other and made naval and coastal civs far more enjoyable. I've been playing Civ Games for 30 years. Civ 7 comes in with the best graphics to date. The diorama style to buildings, cities and topology are a perfect evolution from the flat textures of the original. The UI isn't my favorite of the series but it doesn't bother me either. The updates and changes to the UI have been a step in the right direction. At minimum I find the UI aesthetically pleasing.

The Civ switching mechanic was a bold choice but I think aligns with history in a truly organic way. Does Rome still exist? Does Babylonia still exist? Does any indigenous empire like the Mayans, Aztecs or Shawnee still exist? And the most omnipresent country/empire in the history of the world China is available the whole game as different dynasties respectfully. While it may be a detraction from previous titles, I think being as historically accurate as possible is one of the core values of the series within the scope of you forging an alternate take of said history. If you build it, they built it first. If you conquer, they conquered it first.

The Leaders are well done and has you thinking about how you want to play and rule the world from the get go. This is a change from the nation/empire choosing of the rest of the series. This is one thing where historical accuracy goes out the window but seems necessary in that various figureheads of great nations and empires continue to be relevant. Think how Caesar, Genghis Khan and Napoleon for example still inspire and awe the world we know today. 

Combat is the best of the series for me. The attention to detail of units, buildings, wonders and city states is all wonderfully executed. I'm glad Barbarians are gone forever. The AI still needs cooking. The diplomacy, religion and espionage mechanics still feel like they need to improve and be fine-tuned to truly stand out above previous iterations. The winning conditions and legacy paths still feel hollow and need to be fleshed out more for them to be truly impressive. Winning in Civ 6 for example feels more satisfying than Civ 7. The culture victory is clumsy and is the least exciting and tedious way to win a Civ game I can remember. 

Things I miss or wish were added in regards to previous iterations in the series are numerous. Things like the World Congress, Governors and designing your palace. The fantasy elements that have been included, modded and were stand alone games are something I wish was available, even if they detract from history as it unfolded. I'm talking about my favorite iteration Civilization II: Test of Time. Who doesn't want to play Civ in the world of Middle Earth, Dungeons and Dragons or their favorite anime? A lot of history as we know it, is boring. Fantasy is not boring by it's nature of not being history. 

With my quibbles and hefty price tag to get all content ever made for this game aside, I can't say this is a bad game, it is a good game. It will continue to evolve and it has the chance to be truly great. 

Long live Sid Meier!!!

Having played this game both at launch as well as after successive patches and rebalancing, I believe it has begun to come into its own. Compared to previous installments, VII feels like a step up in terms of the detail and and nuance felt in each era, where you get to experience an immersive look at several civilizations as you build them. Personally I have mixed opinions about the civ switching mechanic, but have landed on it being an interesting experiment for this installment. If you really lean into the civilization and ages mechanics, you can find very fun ways to shape your own playthrough. As an added bonus the game is absolutely gorgeous. I'll leave some pros and cons as of november 2025:

PROS:
+ Civ switching mechanic adds new ways to experience and have fun with empire building. Leader attributes and "mementos" let you further funnel civilization power towards desired victories. 
+ Each age, leader and civilization feels thoroughly researched and implemented.
+ You now level up commanders instead of individual military units. The ability to shape and move the direction of the military/navy/airforce feels better than in any other installment of the franchise. 
+ The diplomatic system is definetely more dynamic and interesting. You have several ways to strengthen yourself and your friends, while sabotaging your enemies if you feel like it. 
+ The AI feels like a better opponent than in previous installments.
+ Multiplayer is straight up fun and competitive!

CONS:
- The UI still needs work following launch. Information about hidden modifiers and the yield loss on buildings from previous ages should be clearly visible.
- The game will feel somewhat "disjointed", abrubt or straight up unimmersive if you are set on playing a single civilization and leader. 
- The later buildings and units in each era feels like they are never used if either you or your opponent have snowballed to a state of being able to end the eras early. As a consequence I seldom get to see the age of gunpowder or use late-game tech such as air combat.
- The inability to swap tiles between cities, or settle on resources makes it more difficult to settle dynamically.
- The progression system seems somewhat limited for long-term strategy players. It is still somewhat fun though!

Overall 8/10 following post-launch changes!

Cons:

It's unfinished and it's very apparent the first time you play the game. There are things that should be displayed or information that should be accessible that just aren't anywhere to be seen. TLDR Conclusion:

Should you buy it? Wait for a sale and I would urge you to try it beforehand maybe find a friend with a copy or family share it idk. What's important is you fall in love with the game in your own way and don't trust other people's opinions (even mine) on something as subjective as videogame preference.

Civilization VII ‚Äì A Bold Reinvention That‚Äôs Unfairly Criticized? (Player Review)

I didn't have the chance to play Civilization VII on launch day, so I missed the initial technical state of the game. Sitting down to play it now, "with fresh eyes," I am genuinely surprised by the wave of critical ratings. Yes, the game introduces changes that might shock veterans, but if you approach it flexibly‚Äîas a new opening for the series and a nod to new players‚Äîit turns out to be a really solid production.

Here are my thoughts on the game in its current state.

üé® Visuals & Atmosphere
The graphics are a huge, positive surprise for me. They are very pleasing to the eye, not overdone, and readable. Most importantly, they maintain that specific "Civ" atmosphere we love. The map feels alive but doesn't overwhelm with an explosion of colors, allowing you to focus on strategy.

‚öôÔ∏è Mechanics: What Works Great?
Firaxis made several bold decisions that, in my opinion, have served the game well:

City-States: The new system is a bullseye. The ability to take them over peacefully and the simplification of their functions mean you immediately know their purpose on the map and how to use them. No more guessing‚Äîit is transparent and logical.

Commanders & Heroes: I really like the evolution in unit management. The new XP system and Commander management (a mix of classic generals and heroes) add depth to the military side of the game.

Settlement Limit: Capping the number of cities is a controversial but good move. It doesn't feel artificial. for players who can manage an empire well, exceeding these limits is possible and profitable, but requires planning. This eliminates mindless city spam (ICS), which plagued previous installments.

‚ö†Ô∏è The Major Flaw: User Interface (UI)
Unfortunately, I have to agree with the complaints about the UI. This is where the developers took a step back, and it clearly needs work from design specialists. The issues are visible on several levels:

Scaling & Empty Space: On a large monitor (I play on a 35-inch screen), the text stretches unnecessarily, and some panels and windows just feel empty. Window sizes should be better fitted to the actual content rather than being artificially pumped up.

Selection Visibility: The indication of a selected option is poor, in some cases almost invisible. There is a lack of clear visual cues. It needs bolder lines, more vivid colors (maybe gold?), or increased transparency for unselected elements to make the active choice pop.

UX Design: A prime example is the Era Goals‚Äîthe lack of a proper background behind the text makes the font blend into the map, rendering it totally unreadable. Previous games proved this can be done better.

üèõÔ∏è Ages & Civ Switching ‚Äì Why the Critics Are Wrong
The most controversy surrounds the Ages system and changing cultures mid-game. I totally disagree with the criticism of this feature.

In my experience, cultural continuity is preserved. The mechanism of unlocking new cultures by completing specific goals in the previous era is excellent. It ensures we naturally evolve into a civilization that fits our current playstyle. Thanks to this, we don't get "stuck" with an early-game choice that makes no sense 200 turns later. Our empire evolves along with our strategy.

Small note: The transition could be slightly smoother. I also miss a clearer schema (a tree?) that would allow for better planning of the cultural development path, rather than just reacting to the here and now.

üí∞ Price & Verdict
Is Civilization VII worth buying? Yes, but... not at full price. The current launch price is definitely too high for the content. in my opinion, a fair price is max 32 Euros. If you see the game on sale around that price point‚Äîgrab it.

In conclusion: Civilization VII is heading in the right direction. It is a refreshing, modern strategy game that suffers mainly from veteran habits and UI shortcomings. If you are looking for a fresh take on the series, I recommend it with a clear conscience‚Äîespecially on sale.

The best and most game-changing parts of Civilization VII are the new city‚Äìtown‚Äìrural system that eases micromanagement, the multi-layered diplomacy built around the new Influence currency, the deeper trade and economy-focused victories, and the Commanders feature that adds real tactical depth to warfare. For the first time, the AI actually feels smarter and can be challenging, which is a big step forward. The game also looks and sounds fantastic ‚Äî it combines the colorful style of Civ VI with the more realistic tone of Civ V, creating a bright yet grounded atmosphere. Still, it‚Äôs a bit disappointing that higher difficulties mostly rely on giving the AI bonuses instead of making it truly more intelligent.

On the downside, city management and the interface can be frustrating. The resource screen starts to break after the third era ‚Äî every turn you have to assign resources, yet finding which one goes to which city is a pain. UI icons can‚Äôt be resized, map generation feels much more limited, and unit variety is smaller (why is there no nuclear submarine?). Some key systems from Civ VI are also missing: there are no UN-like diplomatic institutions, no Golden or Dark Ages, no environmental or natural disaster mechanics, and era effects feel far less meaningful ‚Äî etc. Overall, many features that added long-term strategy and immersion are simply gone or oversimplified, leaving the game a bit shallower.

Some things are more mixed. The new era and civilization transition system is both interesting and awkward. Trying out different civilization combos is fun, but the 150-turn eras feel uneven ‚Äî too fast early on, too slow later. Eras could be split into smaller stages, and transitions should be smoother: wars ending suddenly and units disappearing hurt the flow. It also lets weaker civs catch up too easily in science and military. The game tries to fix this with era bonuses, but they‚Äôre too weak to really balance or create a snowball effect.

In the end, despite all these dramatic changes, Civilization VII still doesn‚Äôt feel as exciting or groundbreaking as a game that appears only once every ten years should. Those still on the fence after Civ VI ‚Äî there‚Äôs still time to wait.

When you first go to start a game, you get to pick a leader, and you get to pick a civ to represent. There are 32 leaders as time of writing this, and 10 starting civs. To add on this, each leader has two passive slots that every leader can choose from. These can be wiped out, or you can spend influence ally with them and they become a city state. You get rewards for doing so, and the rewards depend on what type of city state they where (econ, military, science, influence).

Soon you will meet your first AI controlled player, and you will see that how you interact with them is completely different. You spend influence on diffrent actions. For example, you can spend influence to create open markets between. The AI can then spend influence to meet your action, you both gain more gold a turn, they can stay neutral, you gain more gold then the AI, but they don't have to spend influence, or they can spend influence to block the action. 

As your city grows, you select tiles to work, which is like selecting which tile to work in civ6. There is no more workers, as when you select which tile to work, it will upgrade it. Another thing they changed is buildings. In civ6, you had buildings they where in your city, and districts. Now, every building is built like a district. Each tile can hold two buildings. If you build a building over a tile that is being worked, you can reassign the worker, later, instead of working tiles, you can place workers inside buildings to increase their output. 

As the game progresses, you are pointed to reach one of 4 age goals. Scientific, economic, military, and cultural. Each one have milestones, and a end goal. These will give you bonuses for the next "age". there are 3 ages, and it's basicly a softreset to your units and cities when a age advances. You also pick a new civ to represent, and what civ you can choose depends on your leader, and what actions you have made in the game.

I see why the reviews are mixed, but I personally land on the positive side. I think the game itself is gorgeous and a blast to play. You pick a leader and a civilization (which don't have to match this time around) and get rolling. tl;dr, I liked it a lot but it does have some things that don't work well for me.

PROs -- Here are some things I really like about the new game:

1. You get a one-turn build for your first unit (scout or warrior), which means no more sitting there waiting for that scout to build staring at your city.
2. They've done a great job with the military. Generals really matter now, and they can get your units to whoosh across the continent to kick butt or augment your forces' effectiveness. Both technology and having the right units built can make a huge difference in whether you steamroller your neighbor or not. There are also some crazy geographic situations -- walled cities where you have to crush all the walled segments to capture them, weird bluffs you can shoot down from but not walk up, and rivers slowing your attack and making those "amphibious" units feel so nice.
3. Diplomacy is excellent. People remember your past good behavior and reward you for it. Want open borders and more trade routes? Better play nice. You can also kill city states or befriend them with diplomacy points, and you lose diplomacy points when you capture tons of territory in wars, making the aggressive and peaceful approaches trade off. Sure, you can build improvements with diplomacy points to compensate, but if you just burned down three civilizations you aren't going to win friends and influence people.
4. The exploration is good. In the ancient age you can't cross the ocean (unless you play Tonga) and that means there's still exploring to do in the later ages. 
5. Even though people hate swapping civs, I find it pretty rewarding. One game I played Greece and was a peace out guy who incorporated city states at the end of the age with my massive diplomacy points. However, I was losing. So in the exploration age, I shifted to the Mongols and conquered the entire continent. You don't really "lose all your stuff" when you switch civs; you keep all your territory and if you plan ahead, you can use generals and admirals to keep your units, too. You mostly lose unspent points and your cities revert back to town status for a while. You keep your old capital as a city and have the option to move your capital to one of your largest other cities, which is usually a good idea, and you get to buy a bunch of perks based on what you did in the previous age. So, if you were a science and culture star, you get points in those trees to improve your ability to do those things. I don't know why people hate it so much, since I think it works well, and you just need to spend gold to get your cities back to full city status. It's not like you start from scratch each time.
6. I liked how they handle colonization / exploitation of lands during the middle era. You settle apparently empty lands that are not part of your main continent (using settlers as normal), and then use the resources there to send treasures back home. Is this how it really happened? No, of course not. But is it a lot of fun? Yes it definitely is.
7. There are a lot of smart and subtle design decisions that force interesting trade-offs. Just like how in the diplomacy model being a backstabbing monster and colonizing everyone makes people hate you and gets the city-states signing up to join your enemies, capturing lots of land quickly hits the settlement cap and raises unhappiness. Unhappiness mostly slows down your ability to run a lot of social policies at once, which is another neat mechanic. Spreading your religion means building temples and missionaries to visit all your cities, but you could ignore religion and spend that gold and production on stuff you want like galleons and settlers. All of this is pretty fun.

CONS -- Here are a few things I think need work or that I didn't like:
1. The religion model got rid of missionary on missionary rap battles, so you can no longer defend against them except by building lots more missionaries. This can be super-annoying when your neighbors keep converting your cities. I miss my apostles squishing the annoying little brats who want to talk to me about some carpenter being the son of God. (We follow Judaism around here, bruh. Still waiting on that messiah.)
2. By the modern age, you are often out of spots to build in your cities. This is not so bad if you move your capital around, but in early games I didn't do that and then my most productive city wasn't doing much. 
3. A lot of major civilizations from earlier games are missing and some of the leaders are not leaders, but regular folks. No Zulus or Aztecs in the game, come on!! I find it a little odd that Harriet Tubman is a civ leader, and she's kind of the "nuclear Gandhi" of this game. She has a power that makes you have tons of war weariness when you fight her, but she is the one who often declares war, sending all your cities into spiraling depression because they're being mean to Tubs. I mean, who wouldn't be sad about an emancipation hero invading with two dozen trebuchets, I guess? Ada Lovelace and Jose Rizal are other weird choices. They are cool people but feel out of place as civ leaders.
4. A lot of things in the modern era feel half-done. For example, the modern era has you picking between democracy, communism, and fascism, which is kind of cool but it seems totally arbitrary who picks what, and you can't ever switch. If you make your Prussians into nazis, they will never turn it around and become modern democratic Germany. 
5. Unlocks. I am an unlock junkie in most games, but why do I need to hit Level 7 with civ leader Jose Rizal (apparently a smart guy from the Philippines, which are not even in the game I think) to unlock all his abilities in the game? This is kind of silly. It's a strategy game, not a roguelike platformer.
6. Maybe a pet peeve but since generals have very specific ability sets that are not always the same from general to general, I really want to be able to give them names. Like, one of my generals mostly sits in the capital and boosts production and defense, while another is used for rapidly running to Karakorum and besieging it with catapults. They are not distinguishable without clicking on them to open their ability list.

Overall, though, I have had tons of fun playing it and look forward to seeing what they do next.

TLDR:  The game is slimmed down from other titles, but the content that's there feels cohesive, and most importantly - it's actually fun to play.  This feels more like the original CIV 1 in a lot of ways than civ 5/6.  I'm a big fan.

From my view, it has probably the best combat since civ departed from the doom stacks of units, and possibly just the best combat in a civ game period.  The new mechanic to load units onto a commander and have them move as a single unit took away most of the tedium of having to actually move around the map in civ 5/6 (both of which were just unpleasant to play on the combat front).

The system mechanics feel trimmed down, but also in ways I think dramatically improve actually playing the game.

The unit list is condensed, with one or two "standard" units per age for both land and sea, and then the faction specific units on top of those.  I mostly don't miss the "extra" units, and I appreciate that it makes the civs feel more distinct (a lot of special units in the older games are better off just ignored in favor of powerhouses like crossbow/knights).

Capturing cities is no longer a chore in complete tedium and ridiculousness, where an ungarrisoned city will easily blow away entire armies of units, and a whole war across hundreds of years of game time results in one city changing hands, maybe.

Now cities actually get conquered like they should, but district by fortified district, which means they can last a turn or two against a lone unit without a garrison, but a general dropping an army on an undefended city will easily take it that turn or the next.  Combat is actually enjoyable again, which I feel hasn't been the case since civ 4.

Things I'm mixed on:

- I think the city vs town distinction is probably going to be fine, but I'll have to play longer to really make up my mind.  It keeps the game focused and playable which I like, but also places a lot more emphasis on gold availability.

- I think the "changing civs" each era is fine.  It's not really my preferred approach thematically, but I understand why they do it to "reset" some things between eras.  No more ancient warriors fighting modern riflemen, and the game is better for it.  I wish you could just pick your starting civ again from the list, though. Overall, this is clearly done to reduce pain during gameplay and it works, but it does feel a little tacked on (and possibly a way to try to sell future civs, which I personally won't buy).

- The AI is still bad.  Welcome to civ.

- The UI is missing a lot of mechanic details that are important.  Ex - there's no indication for how far traders can trade, and help buttons for most things in general are just missing.  It's not the end of the world, and I bought it late enough to avoid most of the early glitches and bugs.  

- Science is still far more important than culture/religion, although I may change my tune here as I play more.

- Breaking things out by era makes it feel "smaller" than it really is as a game.  There's a lot of stuff in there, but you don't have to hit it all because the era jumps you to the next spot.  I'm mostly ok with this, but I understand the complaints.

**Mac users** - this game is buttery smooth. I mostly game on PC, but I'm on my Macbook Pro M1 so much time doing software dev that I love having Mac-friendly games. Full screen game mode can be put in its own window, mute on background (looking at you Paradox), no resource demand in background, graphics gorgeous...purrs better than many PC titles. This is about a best I've seen for a Mac launch of any title and if you are Mac user, on sale it's worth it for that alone. 

**God-moders** - I think I'm in the minority (at least among content creators) in how I play this game. Almost never play on deity, barely play multiplayer or competitive. And really don't play to get a "victory"  (devs badly misunderstand this part of the player base). I like to play at a relatively challenging level (~King on Civ 6), and try to get ever wonder, every win condition, all the buildings and ships, etc. all in same game. Super wide, huge maps, marathon, no turn-limits. And often keep playing after "victory" till I do all I want to do. It's this "sandbox" (overused term) playstyle that I absolutely love. Once I've done that, I rinse, repeat. If you're that kind of player, this game has those basics -- not Civ 4, 5, or 6 yet, but better than anything else atm.

**Everyone else** Long-time fan (thousands of hours), fav game series ever. Desperately wanted to get into this. Held out b/c wasn't (and still am not) fan of the age transitions, leader choices, and UI issues I saw raised (Civ-swapping was something I was okay trying and so not a fan, but not a deal-breaker). And primarily, the game was clearly released rushed and broken so no way I would pay the full price they were asking (on principle). Bought it for 35% off with the free DLC. Not even to mention Civ 6. Tl;dr - it doesn't give enough info, hard to tell what anything does, has annoying intrusions, etc.). It's bad enough to make this kind of 4X game less enjoyable. That said, the core "one-more-turn" dopamine loop is here - the core "guide my fledgling empire from scraps to world power" is there. But if they keep patching and working on it, and don't get too greedy with DLCs, there's a "comeback" story here for sure. Because the nuts and bolts are there. If you love this series, this game will end up in your Steam library sooner or later, so I won't say it's a *must* right now, but I'm happy I got it and looking forward to (hopefully) thousands of hours over the years...

I‚Äôve played every Civilization game since the very first one, and in every single version of it there is something that keeps pulling you back.

That said, Civ VII is very much a ‚Äúlove it or hate it‚Äù entry in the series.

[b]Era Transition System ‚Äì Bold but Divisive[/b]

The new era transition system is the most controversial feature and for good reason. Being forced to change your civilization between eras feels unnatural to many players, especially veterans of the series. This alone disappointed a large part of the community.
To be fair, the developers have already announced they are experimenting with new game modes that allow you to keep your civilization from start to finish, which is a very welcome move.

Personally, what bothers me even more is that leaders are now detached from their historical civilizations. I understand how many players may see this as a positive thing that adds variety and [u]replayability[/u], but for me it breaks immersion and historical identity.

[b]Art & Presentation[/b]

One aspect that truly shines to me in Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization VII is its art direction. The visuals are simply beautiful, from the detailed map design and city visuals to the UI, animations, and overall atmosphere. The game does an excellent job at making your empire feel alive as it evolves. Even when I‚Äôm frustrated with certain mechanics, the presentation constantly reminds me of the high production value behind the game.

[b]Bugs, Mods, and Ongoing Support[/b]

Even after all this time since launch, there are still noticeable bugs, and mod compatibility issues remain a real problem. Community content does not always behave as expected, and this hurts one of Civ‚Äôs biggest long-term strengths.

The good news is that the developers are actively supporting the game (for now). Updates do come, and it feels that there is a long-term intent to improve things. That deserves credit.

[b]Price & Monetization[/b]

This is where things get really hard to defend.
At its current price, Civ VII still feels too expensive given the controversies and the uneven quality of the content delivered so far. On top of that, the aggressive monetization of extra content leaves a somewhat bad taste. It often feels like more development resources are being allocated to paid DLC and content packs than to properly fixing the core game.

That said, it is only fair to mention that the developers just released a free content pack, Tides of Power, which can be claimed for free for one month before receiving a price tag. This is a good gesture toward the community, even if it does not fully offset the broader monetization concerns.

[b]Final Verdict[/b]

Civ VII is ambitious, experimental, frustrating, and addictive at the same time. As a lifelong fan of the series, I‚Äôm still playing it heavily, but I can‚Äôt blindly recommend it to everyone at full price. If you love Civilization and enjoy experimenting with new systems, you may find a lot to like here. If you value historical consistency, stability, and polished mod support, you may want to wait.

[b]Recommended with reservations.[/b]

[h1]Overview[/h1]
I love the Civilization series and it‚Äôs in my top 3 favorite game franchises, but Civ 7 feels unfinished at 9 months post launch. The game has a lot of potential, but still has frustrating design choices, missing features, and UI issues.

[hr]

[h2]What I Like[/h2]

[b]Commanders system[/b]
Combat feels more strategic and unique with different commanders. This is one of the best additions to the series in my opinion. It also makes moving armies much less tedious. Though I still wish there was an area select option like in other 4x / RTS games.

[b]Momentos & Challenges[/b]
These actually give me a reason to finish games and try new leaders. However, the Unlock All Momentos mod is a lifesaver since reaching the level 9 unlocks on some leaders can be a grind.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The game looks great in early eras. I really like how the entire map looks like a miniature diorama. However,  later on through the game the cities and district tiles feel cramped and make the terrain of the tiles they are built on hard to see. This can cause some accidental and unwanted moves when you cant tell there is a giant cliff between two tiles when you are attempting to assault a district.  And for me personally, this causes some pretty bad eye strain, especially compared to Civ 6.

[hr]

[h2]Mixed Feelings[/h2]

[b]Ages system[/b]
[list]
[*]The era system adds decent replayability and some fun civ/leader synergies. These builds aren't as impactful as a game like Stellaris, but it is a nice breath of fresh air. This also reminds me of the "Civ Blitz" community mod/mode from Civ 6 where you drafted every part of your civ from leaders & civ abilities to units & buildings. 
[*]The future-era starts are enjoyable, though, I wish we could select which previous-age civ we would have played so the advanced age start would come with the traditions, improvements, and/or quarters of previous-age civs we would have wanted.
[*]Continuity Mode fixed some of my original frustrations with the ages system. Making the transition feel more like it did in Humankind. Though I'm still not sure how I feel about all units upgrading, since sometimes a unique unit from a previous age can still be better than the new-age upgrade.
[/list]
[h3]Legacy Paths / Victory Conditions[/h3]

[b]Antiquity Age[/b]
I find all of the legacy paths in this age relatively fun and achievable regardless of playstyle. 

[b]Exploration Age[/b]

Religion is bland and hard to manage. The bonuses for tirelessly working to keep a majority religion in either your own cities or other civs is not worth the small bonuses. I hardly find myself playing around religion.

Science in this age is easy but not very fun since if you want to keep up with the AI or other players you need specialists anyways.

Economic and military legacies force focus on the New World, which can be inconsistent depending on map generation. Sometimes you will never be able to colonize the new world. Other times the AI in distant lands will seem to have done nothing the entire previous age. And ff you want to focus on fighting your enemies in your homeland that you made in the previous age, you don‚Äôt get points towards the military path unless you pick Mongolia.

[b]Modern Age[/b]

Feels too fast overall. This age seems to go by way too quick.

Culture is mostly a race to explorers & artifacts.

Economic legacy is fun, but requiring both a railroad and a port to build a factory (to connect the settlement to your capital) is slightly too restrictive, especially for smaller island settlements where tiles for districts are limited since the railroad occupies and entire tile.

Military is okay. I would even say I enjoy this the most in singleplayer, but this can drag multiplayer turns on for way too long (if you play without turn timers).

Science is just a bland ‚Äúcomplete projects‚Äù gameplay. At least in Civ 6 you could try and rush the projects by chopping resources. 

[hr]

[h2]What I Dislike[/h2]

[b]District adjacency[/b]
Districts being required to be next to other districts is my biggest issue with this game. Misplacing early settlements or other districts can lock cities out of options. Humankind handled this better with Hamlets which allowed us to place other districts next to a hamlet which could be placed anywhere in the settlement on a valid tile.

[b]Borders[/b]
This one is a personal pet peeve, but maxed borders don‚Äôt keep expanding like in past Civ games. This causes the map to feel like it isn't as "filled in", and topping this with the settlement limit penalties, I often end the games with a map that has vast areas that aren't claimed. Also please bring back the map replay from Civ 5 I'm begging you firaxis.

[b]UI[/b]
Lacks basic features from previous Civ games. Important information is buried or unclear. I don't hate the overall look as much as some people, but some very basic QoL features (like queuing multiple Techs/Civics) are missing.

[b]Scenarios[/b]
None at launch, which is disappointing since I really enjoyed these since playing Civilization Revolution on the xbox.

[b]Civs & Leaders[/b]
The base roster is okay, but some DLC civs should have been included at launch. England/Great Britain not being a base-game civ is crazy. Also ending Ghandi's reign over our nuclear arsenals is tragic.

[hr]

[h2]Verdict[/h2]
If this were a smaller indie game, or  starting at a lower price point I‚Äôd recommend it. At full AAA price, it feels unfinished. I pre-ordered the highest tier and have (and will continue to) put hundreds of hours into it, but I can‚Äôt fully recommend it right now.

[b]Alternatives[/b]

Want a taste of the eras system (and some interesting choices for civs)? Try Humankind.

Want a refined Civ experience? Stick to previous entries. Especially with the civ modding communities, who continue to breath life into previous civ games. 

Also, try Vox Populi for Civ 5. It is amazing.

[hr]

For me, this game fundamentally missed the mark and significantly damaged the Civilization franchise's reputation. It takes the core elements of a great strategy game and transforms the experience into something almost unrecognizable and deeply unsatisfying.

My primary frustration lies with the periodic resets and radical shifts in gameplay.  The core fun of Civilization is building incredible momentum‚Äîseeing your empire grow, your technology advance, and your victory inch closer. This game repeatedly interrupts that feeling.

Introducing a mechanic where you are forced to reset your progress, remove units, change your capital city, and select a new civilization not once, but multiple times, is a design choice I simply cannot comprehend.  Just as I would start to see some wins and eke out a victory against the AI, the game would initiate this scenario. This felt less like a strategic evolution and more like being arbitrarily forced to start over, which is contrary to the spirit of the Civ series.

I genuinely wanted to enjoy this game. I committed a significant number of hours and experimented with the new era settings, hoping it would click. Unfortunately, the game's core mechanics, particularly the constant disruptive resets, prevent it from being a good experience.

If you are a long-time fan expecting the traditional, sprawling, empire-building experience of previous Civilization titles, be warned: this is not that game.

If you are cool with radical change and enjoy a strategy game that repeatedly forces you to tear down your progress and restart with new conditions, then you might find this game fun.

If you crave the classic Civ formula‚Äîthe slow build, the cumulative momentum, and the preservation of your progress‚ÄîI would strongly advise against purchasing this title.

Initially I wanted to befriend one so that I could conquer the other, however the new diplomacy features are so surface level and scant that it didn't really seem like it was possible. The tooltips do very little to help clear any confusion one may have as they usually go in depth on one specific thing, but explain nothing else about anything other than that one thing it wants you to do. We all ended up being enemies.

I did really enjoy the new commander focused combat style and I found war to be one of the only enjoyable aspects of the game. (I always enjoy war in civ, but I also like to do the science and culture, and religion victories or play styles) as a matter of fact, I found it to be really one of the /i only /i aspects of the game that have any amount of depth to them. Half of the time I found that the game consisted mostly of me moving my soldiers around hitting next turn and then the game tells me I did something and to choose something for some reason I don't really understand giving me a bonus I don't really understand. Most of the game feels like it's on autopilot so you can focus on action... but I want to be in charge of everything. If there is a way to track things like celebrations or any of the other 50 random seeming events that just happen to you, I was not able to find it. 

You may blame me, "dude, you didn't look hard enough and blame the game that you couldn't think hard enough." but believe me, the UI is so atrocious that you struggle to track the things that they do put in front of you! Speaking of things they make difficult to see, the camera doesn't track action. if your troops get attacked or something happens on the AI turn, you don't get to see it unless your camera just so happens to be hovering over the area at the time. Further, small though it may be, it can be difficult to tell if it's your turn. There is no audio chime or visual cue other than a minor icon change in the bottom right. it will not jump to a unit either. 
This is an issue because it means that you don't know if it's actually the new turn or if a unit completed it's previous order and needs a new one. 

Now let's talk about ages... They suck, and it ruins a great deal of mechanics that should be fine otherwise. Firstly, since civs are only meant for one age, that means that each civ's mechanic is incredibly shallow because it only needs to work for one age, not an entire game. This usually makes them very narrow and shallow. Second, the game needs things to go on and that means it needs to artificially undo your progress just to ensure that when the next age starts you don't just keep rolling. It does this via crisis. in my case it was just making my cities unhappy because I was militaristic. I had done very well in spite of a two front war and had both other civilizations on my continent down to like 2 cities each. No matter how many resources or happiness buildings I made, the cities/ towns  NEEDED to be angry and revolt. I moved troops to defend against impending rebellions and was annoyed but figured this is just what happens when you expand too far. Not too bad, and maybe it'll be fun and challenging since I'm demolishing everyone else.

No rebellion came, they didn't become free cities or rebels or anything. IT JUST GAVE THE CITIES BACK TO MY ENEMIES AND ENDED THE AGE. So I had to spend the start of the next age recovering and then wiped them. Now came the age of religion.

Religion may as well not be in the game. you can train a missionary, you can use two charges of that missionary to fully convert a city. This concludes the impact of religion on the game. 

At this point, without any effort, merchants, or even really building anything money focused, I was making 300 gold a turn in spite of having a giant military. It was basically costing me nothing. by turn 30 of the modern age I managed to conquer the entire world. this was not hard to do because THERE WERE ONLY TWO CONTINENTS AND 6 CIVS INCLUDING ME IN THE ENTIRE GAME. I honestly could not relay to you what I did research wise, as it did not seem to matter, nor could I tell you about my culture, because it did not really seem to matter. In essence, the only thing that mattered in the entire game was managing my army, you can safely ignore nearly all other mechanics in the entire game and it will not matter past the first age. Sure I was trying to win a domination victory, but I shouldn't be able to literally not engage with ANY of the other mechanics of the game. By the modern age I didn't even bother converting towns to cities anymore. I had more than enough money, but it just was more hassle having them build things for me because I was literally just winning without them so what would the point even be?

in short, the combat is the only interesting part of the game and after you secured an advantage in that aspect, it isn't even fun or interesting anymore.
